The exact reasons behind Reynald de Chatillon's decision to subject the Patriarch of Antioch, Aimery of Limoges, to the cruel treatment of being covered with honey and left exposed to insects on the roof of his castle are not entirely clear. However, it is believed that Reynald was motivated by a desire to gain leverage over the Patriarch and to assert his dominance over the Church.

At the time of the incident, Reynald was a powerful lord in the Kingdom of Jerusalem, and he had clashed with Aimery and other church leaders over a variety of issues, including control of territory and political power. By subjecting the Patriarch to such a humiliating and degrading treatment, Reynald may have been attempting to demonstrate his own authority and to intimidate his opponents.

It is also possible that Reynald was motivated by a desire for personal vengeance against Aimery, who had previously excommunicated him for his violent actions against Muslims. Whatever his motivations, Reynald's decision to subject the Patriarch to such inhumane treatment was widely condemned, both by his fellow Christians and by the Muslim leaders who he was fighting against.
